title: Beat and Downbeat Tracking in Performance MIDI Using an End-to-End Transformer Architecture
author: Sebastian MURGUL (Klangio GmbH), Michael HEIZMANN (Karlsruhe Institute of Technology), ...
relevance_why: The paper's approach to beat tracking using a transformer architecture could inspire novel methodologies in audio processing domains, particularly in tasks involving rhythm analysis and transcription.
background: Beat tracking is the task of identifying the rhythmic structure within musical performances, crucial for music transcription and rhythmic analysis.
contribution: This paper introduces an end-to-end transformer-based model for detecting beats and downbeats in MIDI performances, achieving superior accuracy compared to traditional methods.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods for beat tracking often relied on hidden Markov models or audio-based techniques, primarily designed for spectrograms.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work utilizes a transformer architecture specifically for MIDI data, allowing for more effective handling of temporal dependencies and improved accuracy.

key_innovation: The model leverages a novel preprocessing pipeline and dynamic data augmentations to enhance the robustness and generalizability of beat tracking across various datasets.
real_world_impact: This research could significantly improve MIDI-based musical applications, enhancing automated transcription systems and rhythm analysis tools used in various audio and music technology fields.
limitations: The model's performance may be less effective on datasets with variable timing that are less accurately represented in MIDI files.

new_terms.MIDI: **Musical Instrument Digital Interface** is a technical standard used for recording and playing back music on digital synthesizers that allows different instruments to communicate.
new_terms.transformer architecture: **Transformer architecture** is a type of neural network model designed for handling sequential data, which utilizes self-attention mechanisms to capture dependencies within the data.
